awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A highly-scalable, rapid, in-season approach to tune a nitrogen model for accurate prediction of a corn crop’s remaining nitrogen need
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a novel artificial intelligence technology that enables U.S. corn farmers to optimize nitrogen fertilizer applications based on field characteristics, rainfall and growing conditions. More efficient use of nitrogen fertilizer will reduce the carbon footprint of U.S. agriculture because more than 10% of the energy consumed in the U.S. agricultural sector goes toward the production of nitrogen fertilizer for corn. Because nitrogen fertilizer is a critical driver of both input costs and yield, this technology will improve the profitability of U.S. farmers by reducing input costs and maximizing corn yields. This project may enable corn production that creates less nitrogen fertilizer pollution, which threatens human health, degrades aquatic ecosystems and emits greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change. A key social element of this project is a teaching module for middle-school science students that will blend content on soil science, agronomy, and crop management with the challenges faced by U.S. corn farmers to follow best management practices.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to demonstrate the technical feasibility of using machine learning to evaluate the amount of yellowness on the lowest corn leaves visible in images taken from low-cost cameras mounted on ground robots. Characteristic yellowness on corn leaves is a strong indicator of stress caused by insufficient nitrogen, a key nutrient. A prototype neural network model will be iteratively improved, in part by dramatically increasing the available training imagery over the course of this Phase I project. Imagery will be collected on field trials set up across several Mid-Western states. Preliminary data suggest that the extent of characteristic yellowness is an indicator of accumulated nitrogen stress that is observable only under the canopy and not via airborne sensors. A commercially available nitrogen model will be used to estimate accumulated nitrogen stress across small plots created by manipulating the amount of added nitrogen fertilizer when corn is about 1-2 feet high. Tuning will occur by adjusting key model parameters through simulation until the differences are minimized between observed and modeled accumulated nitrogen stress across a field’s small plots. Parallel software development will improve prototype codes running simulations of a leading nitrogen model, enabling rapid model tuning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project used computer vision and machine learning to identify individual leaves of corn plants. Several positions of low-cost RGB cameras were evaluated to determine an ideal position for mounting on an unmanned ground vehicle (UGV) or ground robot. Identified leaves were subsequently analyzed for the appearance of characteristic yellowness, which can be linked to nitrogen stress. The performance of the automated nitrogen-stress evaluator compared favorably to results of humans scoring the yellowness in a set of several thousand test images. Various nitrogen stress conditions were created in field trials at three sites in MN and IA. A commercially-available model was used to predict soil nitrate availability, from which predictions of accumulated leaf yellowness were made. An analysis framework was developed to enable testing a range of model parameter values to identify those parameters that cause the modeled results to most closely match the observed nitrogen stress (yellowness) conditions.

This project has demonstrated the feasibility of collecting and rapidly analyzing under-canopy imagery for characteristic leaf yellowness onboard UGVs. This information will subsequently be used to identify a model of a given crop field with well-tuned parameters that would be ideal for predicting how much nitrogen fertilizer should be applied to maximize efficiency of nitrogen use. More efficient use of nitrogen fertilizer, an expensive input, has the potential to increase farmer profitability. Increasing nitrogen use efficiency also will lower the carbon footprint of corn farming; the production of nitrogen fertilizer requires a massive amount of fossil fuel-based energy, yet a substantial amount of this nitrogen is wasted and does not end up in the crop. The proposed project will help reduce the leakage of nitrogen from agricultural landscapes, which undercuts farmer stewardship because of water pollution and emissions of greenhouse gases. Excess nitrogen in groundwater is a human health threat, whereas nitrogen introduced into surface waters leads to excess algal growth (eutrophication) and the linked phenomenon of low-oxygen (hypoxia) in bays and estuaries.


Last Modified: 08/01/2023
Modified by: Kent Cavender-Bares
